title: Moneysupermarket's share price nosedives as finance division struggles
text:
Shares in online comparison website Moneysupermarket slumped over 10 per cent after the group admitted it was still having problems with 'product availability' across its money arm.

The group's money division, which spans everything from credit cards to travel money, shrank 5 per cent to £20.6million in the three months to the end of September.

While the group's money division struggled, overall, the group's total revenue grew 4 per cent year-on-year to £100.9million.

Revenue: While the group's money division struggled, overall, the group's total revenue grew 4 per cent year-on-year to £100.9million

The company's insurance arm sales rose 3 per cent to £50million.

'Insurance grew in a subdued premium environment despite some volatility in our natural search rankings,' Moneysupermarket said.

Meanwhile, the group's home services division, which includes energy, saw revenue rise 21 per cent to £17.7million.

Ofgem's introduction in January of an upper limit on energy prices for customers on default tariffs sparked fears that the number of customers changing to a better deal, a key part of Moneysupermarket's revenues, would drop.

But, the latest available figures, from August, show that switching is actually on the rise.

The price cap rose three months after being introduced, but fell again earlier in October.

Moneysupermarket's chief executive, Mark Lewis, said: 'The group continued to grow in the quarter, with strong trading in energy showing that there are still big savings to be made by customers even though the price cap is lower.'

He added: 'Even better, our reinvent strategy continues to do more for our customers - the new Moneysupermarket Energy Monitor service means our customers need never overpay for energy ever again.'

Moneysupermarket said it expects its money arm to weaken further by the end of the year, but remains on track to meet market expectations.

Struggling: Shares in comparison website Moneysupermarket fell over 10% this morning

Earlier this morning, the group's share price fell over 10 per cent. At present, its shares are down 8.97 per cent or 34.70p to 352.30p.

David Madden, an analyst at CMC Markets, said: 'Should the consumer climate continue to be fragile, more people might start to use the money-saving website as a way of trimming their outgoings.'

Broker Liberum said that the group's weaker performance in money and insurance should be attributed to 'subdued market conditions as opposed to Moneysupermarket's competitive position within price comparison', adding that Moneysupermarket's new strategy is a 'fundamental game changer', using first party data to push personalised deals to consumers.
